text: could you uncook an egg actually yes you
can scientists at the University of
California Irvine figured that one out
while testing a way to untangle proteins
used in medical research okay it's not
something you're gonna do at home but
let us explain when an egg is submerged
in boiling water the heat tangles its
proteins causing them to clump together
into new forms eventually the gup-e egg
white gels into a solid so how do you
unbel a hard-boiled egg using the
principle of microscopic reversibility
that science speak for anything done can
be undone you dissolve the boiled egg
white and urea a chemical that
lubricates and separates the clumped up
proteins causing them to shift around
the result is a clear protein called
lysozyme the lysozyme is placed into
something called a vortex fluidic device
which spins at a mind-boggling 5,000 rpm
inside the proteins are pulled by shear
force until they snap back into the
original untangled array this isn't just
a cooking show stunt the process shows
promise as a way to simplify the
manufacturing of complex prescription
drugs and may streamline reuse of
proteins in cancer research as well but
that's for the future for now we're just
answering the question could you uncook
an egg yes with a vortex fluidic device
or you could just head down to the
grocery store and buy another dozen eggs
